sn36.20:4.1: “Mendicants, in one explanation I’ve spoken of two feelings. In another explanation I’ve spoken of three feelings, or five, six, eighteen, thirty-six, or a hundred and eight feelings.
sn36.20:4.2: I’ve taught the Dharma with all these explanations.
sn36.20:4.3: This being so, you can expect that those who don’t concede, approve, or agree with what has been well spoken
sn36.20:4.4: will argue, quarrel, and fight, continually wounding each other with barbed words.
sn36.20:4.5: I’ve taught the Dharma with all these explanations.
sn36.20:4.6: This being so, you can expect that those who do concede, approve, or agree with what has been well spoken
sn36.20:4.7: will live in harmony, appreciating each other, without fighting, blending like milk and water, and regarding each other with kindly eyes.
sn36.20:5.1: There are these five kinds of sensual stimulation. …
sn36.20:5.2: It’s possible that wanderers who follow other paths might say:
sn36.20:5.3: ‘The ascetic Gotama spoke of the cessation of perception and feeling, and he includes it in happiness.
sn36.20:5.5: “Mendicants, when wanderers who follow other paths say this, you should say to them:
sn36.20:5.6: ‘Reverends, when the Buddha describes what’s included in happiness, he’s not just referring to pleasant feeling.
sn36.20:5.7: The Realized One describes pleasure as included in happiness wherever it’s found, and in whatever context.’”
